Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Wireless Invention Kits and Media Engagement Platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
Beginners face barriers to music making; music notation, technique, and theory can seem like pre-requisites to meaningful musical experiences. Current electronic music technologies are too complex, constrained, or expensive. Educators and children need better tools that support learning through creative tinkering with technology and music. Current tools are too complicated for beginners, not open-ended enough to support diverse student interests, inadequately supported by creative pedagogy and support materials, and too expensive. This I-Corps team is developing a musical invention kit that enables users to transform everyday materials, like paper, cardboard and aluminum foil, into musical instruments. The kit connects users' tangible creations to a music-making app in a web browser or mobile device. The proposed design is both simple, lowering the barriers to entry for musical creation, and powerful, enabling kids, families and teachers to invent and play with music and sounds they love.

The proposed technology consists of a kit of physical and electronic materials that, together with custom web and mobile applications, enable kids to design and build musical instruments, interfaces and controllers. At the core of the kit is a microcontroller break-out board with analog, capacitive and high-resistance switching inputs. The microcontroller communicates with our custom mobile and web music and media applications via low-power Bluetooth enabling children to work with our kits avoiding the clutter, complexity and limitations of wires. Also included are paper templates pre-printed with conductive ink traces and connectors. These templates can be cut, customized, extended, drawn-on with pencil lead and conductive ink, and folded into physical objects such as custom music controllers and interactive storyboards. Tutorials and an inspiring online community support users' creative work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The team of Alex Ruthmann (Primary Investigaor), Eric Rosenbaum (Entrepreneurial Lead), and Erica Gruen (Business Mentor), completed the goals of the iCorps program by pursuing over 100 customer interviews with potential customers, end users, and partners. After our iCorps curriculum and a "Go" decision, we continued prototype development around our wireless invention kits and web media platform throughout the rest of 2015. 

During 2015, Ruthmann and Gruen integrated their learnings from the iCorps program and from Lean Launchpad Educators' training into two courses taught at New York University focused on entrepreneurship in the music business and technology design for music making and learning. These courses are offered each year to students interested in music at NYU.

To date, Ruthmann has raised $160,000 in development contracts from the Urban Arts Partnership, Chamber Music Society of Detroit, Theolonius Monk Institute of Jazz to further refine and apply our core technologies. We were accepted into the NYC Media Lab Combine Accelerator program in January 2016 and received a $25,000 grant to continue our customer discovery process with major kids media partners. We will continue our involvement in the accelerator through Q2 2016.

In March of 2016, Ruthmann and Gruen founded MusEDWorks, PBC - a Delaware public benefit corporation for the purpose of commercializing technologies initially prototyped as part of the iCorps program. We are currently finalizing the licensing agreement with New York University to MusEDWorks, and are pusuring our first commercial licensing agreements with major toy, media, and educational technology partners. We will be releasing our first direct to consumer apps and software products in late 2016. 

Interested parties can follow our work at http://musedworks.com/.
